Meal Planning']","# Meal Plan Overview

This meal plan is designed to support a healthy, balanced macro approach for an active 33-year-old male (180 cm, 80 kg) with no specific fitness goal noted (maintenance supportive). Meals include a variety of protein sources, whole grains, fruits, and vegetables to ensure nutrient diversity and satiety. Snacks are included to balance energy levels throughout the day. Adjust portion sizes as needed depending on actual activity intensity.

james.martin4@example.com,FitLife2025!,James,Martin,1990-06-15,M,180,80,Active,"High-protein, low-carb, nutrient-dense","I want a high-protein, low-carb meal plan around 3200 calories to support my active lifestyle and muscle maintenance.","# Meal Plan Overview
- Protein (average per day): ~240 g (30% of calories)
- Carbs (average per day): ~160 g (20% of calories)
- Fat (average per day): ~128 g (36% of calories)
• Designed for an active male (180 cm, 80 kg) aiming for muscle maintenance with a high-protein, low-carb, nutrient-dense approach.
• Meals feature a variety of nutrient-dense animal & plant proteins, healthy fats (olive oil, nuts, avocado), and controlled lower-carb veggies and fruits.
• Carbs come primarily from veggies, nuts, legumes, and limited whole grains/fruits to maintain low-carb profile.
• Daily meals structured as 3 main meals + 1-2 snacks to support energy needs and muscle recovery.
• Simple, accessible ingredients offered, with variety to prevent meal fatigue.

column1: - Cauliflower (1 head or 300g processed as rice)
- Vegetables: spinach, kale, broccoli, asparagus, mushrooms, zucchini, bell peppers, tomatoes, Brussels sprouts, green beans, cucumbers
- Nuts & Seeds: walnuts (50g), almonds (60g), pumpkin seeds (15g), sunflower seeds (15g), chia seeds (1 tbsp), flaxseed (1 tbsp)
## Recipe 1: High-Protein Scrambled Eggs with Smoked Salmon and Spinach (Day 1 Breakfast)
1. Heat olive oil in a non-stick pan over medium heat.
2. Add spinach and sauté until wilted (~1-2 mins).
3. Beat eggs and pour into pan, scrambling gently with spinach.
4. When eggs are partially cooked, add smoked salmon pieces.
5. Continue cooking until eggs are fully set. Serve warm.
## Recipe 2: Beef & Black Bean Chili (Day 4 Lunch)
- 50g canned black beans, drained and rinsed
- Chili powder, cumin, salt, pepper to taste
1. Heat olive oil in a pan over medium heat. Add onions and garlic; sauté until softened.
2. Add ground beef, cook until browned.
3. Stir in bell pepper, black beans, and spices.
4. Simmer for 10-15 minutes until flavors blend and mixture thickens. Serve hot.
## Recipe 3: Shrimp Stir-Fry with Zucchini Noodles (Day 3 Dinner)
1. Heat coconut oil in a wok or large pan over medium-high heat.
2. Add garlic, sauté briefly. Add shrimp and cook until pink and opaque (~3-4 mins). Remove shrimp from pan.
3. Add zucchini noodles and bell peppers to pan, stir-fry for 2-3 mins until tender-crisp.
4. Return shrimp to pan, mix well, season with salt and pepper, and serve immediately.

[a] Food intake patterns at 1,000, 1,200, and 1,400 calories are designed to meet the nutritional needs of 2- to 8-year-old children. Patterns from 1,600 to 3,200 calories are designed to meet the nutritional needs of children 9 years and older and adults. If a child 4 to 8 years of age needs more calories and, therefore, is following a pattern at 1,600 calories or more, his/her recommended amount from the dairy group should be 2.5 cups per day. Children 9 years and older and adults should not use the 1,000-, 1,200-, or 1,400-calorie patterns.

[b] Foods in each group and subgroup are:

Vegetables

Dark-green vegetables: All fresh, frozen, and canned dark-green leafy vegetables and broccoli, cooked or raw: for example, broccoli; spinach; romaine; kale; collard, turnip, and mustard greens.

Red and orange vegetables: All fresh, frozen, and canned red and orange vegetables or juice, cooked or raw: for example, tomatoes, tomato juice, red peppers, carrots, sweet potatoes, winter squash, and pumpkin.

Legumes (beans and peas): All cooked from dry or canned beans and peas: for example, kidney beans, white beans, black beans, lentils, chickpeas, pinto beans, split peas, and edamame (green soybeans). Does not include green beans or green peas.

This chapter focuses on the fourth Dietary Guideline:

1. Follow a healthy eating pattern across the lifespan. All food and beverage choices matter. Choose a healthy eating pattern at an appropriate calorie level to help achieve and maintain a healthy body weight, support nutrient adequacy, and reduce the risk of chronic disease.

2. Focus on variety, nutrient density,

and amount. To meet nutrient needs within calorie limits, choose a variety of nutrient-dense foods across and within all food groups in recommended amounts.

4. Shift to healthier food and beverage choices. Choose nutrient-dense foods and beverages across and within all food groups in place of less healthy choices. Consider cultural and personal preferences to make these shifts easier to accomplish and maintain.

5. Support healthy eating patterns for all. Everyone has a role in helping to create and support healthy eating patterns in multiple settings nationwide, from home to school to work to communities. The chapter includes quantitative information on intakes and common sources of food groups, their subgroups, and other dietary components, including nutrients. The chapter also includes strategies to help shift current eating patterns toward the healthy patterns described in Chapter 1. Complementary strategies to support individuals in their effort to make shifts are discussed in greater detail in Chapter 3. Everyone Has a Role in Supporting Healthy Eating Patterns.

More than half of the population is meeting or exceeding total grain and total protein foods recommendations, but, as discussed later in the chapter, are not meeting the recommendations for the subgroups within each of these food groups.

Most Americans exceed the recommendations for added sugars, saturated fats, and sodium.

In addition, the eating patterns of many are too high in calories. Calorie intake over time, in comparison to calorie needs, is best evaluated by measuring body weight status. The high percentage of the population that is overweight or obese suggests that many in the United States overconsume calories. As documented in the Introduction, Table I-1, more than two-thirds of all adults and nearly one- third of all children and youth in the United States are either overweight or obese.

Current eating patterns can be moved toward healthier eating patterns by making shifts in food choices over time. Making these shifts can help support a healthy body weight, meet nutrient needs, and lessen the risk for chronic disease.', 'Calorie Level of Pattern[a]

This high-protein, low-carb, nutrient-dense meal plan supports an active lifestyle aiming to maintain or improve lean muscle mass with controlled carbohydrate intake. The plan includes a variety of lean proteins, healthy fats, and fiber-rich vegetables, keeping carbs low to moderate. Meals are designed to be simple, accessible, and flexible for substitutions.

Healthy Intake: Healthy eating patterns include a variety of protein foods in nutrient-dense forms. The protein foods group comprises a broad group of foods

Page 23 — 2015-2020 Dietary Guidelines for Americans • Chapter 1

from both animal and plant sources and includes several subgroups: seafood; meats, poultry, and eggs; and nuts, seeds, and soy products. Legumes (beans and peas) may also be considered part of the protein foods group as well as the vegetables group (see the About Legumes (Beans and Peas) call-out box). Protein also is found in some foods from other food groups (e.g., dairy). The recommendation for protein foods in the Healthy U.S.-Style Eating Pattern at the 2,000-calorie level is 5½ ounce- equivalents of protein foods per day.

Key Nutrient Contributions: Protein foods are important sources of nutrients in addition to protein, including B vitamins (e.g., niacin, vitamin B12, vitamin B6, and riboflavin), selenium, choline, phosphorus, zinc, copper, vitamin D, and vitamin E). Nutrients provided by various types of protein foods differ. For example, meats provide the most zinc, while poultry provides the most niacin. Meats, poultry, and seafood provide heme iron, which is more bioavailable than the non-heme iron found in plant sources. Heme iron is especially important for young children and women who are capable of becoming pregnant or who are pregnant. Seafood provides the most vitamin B12 and vitamin D, in addition to almost all of the polyunsaturated omega-3 fatty acids, eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA), and docosahexaenoic acid (DHA), in the Patterns (see the About Seafood call-out box). Eggs provide the most choline, and nuts and seeds provide the most vitamin E. Soy products are a source of copper, manganese, and iron, as are legumes.

Considerations: For balance and flexibility within the food group, the Healthy U.S.\xad Style Eating Pattern includes weekly recommendations for the subgroups: seafood; meats, poultry, and eggs; and nuts, seeds, and soy products. A specific

recommendation for at least 8 ounce- equivalents of seafood per week also is included for the 2,000-calorie level (see the About Seafood call-out box). One-half ounce of nuts or seeds counts as 1 ounce-equivalent of protein foods, and because they are high in calories, they should be eaten in small portions

and used to replace other protein foods rather than being added to the diet. When selecting protein foods, nuts and seeds should be unsalted, and meats and poultry should be consumed in lean forms. Processed meats and processed poultry are sources of sodium and saturated fats, and intake of these products can

be accommodated as long as sodium, saturated fats, added sugars, and total calories are within limits in the resulting eating pattern (see the About Meats and Poultry call-out box). The inclusion of protein foods from plants allows vegetarian options to be accommodated.', 'Source of Goal[a]

1.6', 'Importance of Calorie Balance Within Healthy Eating Patterns

Managing calorie intake is fundamental to achieving and maintaining calorie balance—the balance between the calories taken in from foods and the calories expended from metabolic processes and physical activity. The best way to determine whether an eating pattern is at an appropriate number of calories is to monitor body weight and adjust calorie intake and expenditure in physical activity based on changes in weight over time.

All foods and many beverages contain calories, and the total number of calories varies depending on the macronutrients in a food. On average, carbohydrates and protein contain 4 calories per gram, fats contain 9 calories per gram, and alcohol has 7 calories per gram. The total number of calories a person needs each day varies depending on a number of factors, including the person’s age, sex, height, weight, and level of physical activity (see Appendix 2). In addition, a need to lose, maintain, or gain weight and other factors affect how many calories should be consumed.

All Americans—children, adolescents, adults, and older adults—are encouraged to achieve and/or maintain a healthy body weight. General guidance for achieving and maintaining a healthy body weight is provided below, and Appendix 8. Federal Resources for Information on Nutrition and Physical Activity provides additional resources, including an evolving array of tools to facilitate Americans’ adoption of healthy choices.

Children and adolescents are encouraged to maintain calorie balance to support normal growth and

development without promoting excess weight gain. Children and adolescents who are overweight or obese should change their eating and physical activity behaviors to maintain or reduce their rate of weight gain while linear growth occurs, so that they can reduce body mass index (BMI) percentile toward a healthy range.

Before becoming pregnant, women are encouraged to achieve and maintain a healthy weight, and

women who are pregnant are encouraged to gain weight within gestational weight gain guidelines.[8]

Adults who are obese should change their eating and physical activity behaviors to prevent additional weight gain and/or promote weight loss. Adults who are overweight should not gain additional weight, and those with one or more CVD risk factors (e.g., hypertension and hyperlipidemia) should change their eating and physical activity behaviors to lose weight. To lose weight, most people need to reduce the number of calories they get from foods and beverages and increase their physical activity. For a weight loss of 1 to 1½ pounds per week, daily intake should be reduced by 500 to 750 calories. Eating patterns that contain 1,200 to 1,500 calories each day can help most women lose weight safely, and eating patterns that contain 1,500 to 1,800 calories each day are suitable for most men for weight loss. In adults who are overweight or obese, if reduction in total calorie intake is achieved, a variety of eating patterns can produce weight loss, particularly in the first 6 months to 2 years;[9] however, more research is needed on the health implications of consuming these eating patterns long-term.

Older adults, ages 65 years and older, who are overweight or obese are encouraged to prevent additional

weight gain. Among older adults who are obese, particularly those with CVD risk factors, intentional weight loss can be beneficial and result in improved quality of life and reduced risk of chronic diseases and associated disabilities.

[8] Institute of Medicine (IOM) and National Research Council (NRC). Weight gain during pregnancy: Reexamining the guidelines. Washington (DC): The National Academies Press; 2009.', 'About This Chapter

This chapter focuses on the fourth Dietary Guideline:

1. Follow a healthy eating pattern across the lifespan. All food and beverage choices matter. Choose a healthy eating pattern at an appropriate calorie level to help achieve and maintain a healthy body weight, support nutrient adequacy, and reduce the risk of chronic disease.

2. Focus on variety, nutrient density,

and amount. To meet nutrient needs within calorie limits, choose a variety of nutrient-dense foods across and within all food groups in recommended amounts.

3. Limit calories from added sugars and saturated fats and reduce sodium intake. Consume an

eating pattern low in added sugars, saturated fats, and sodium. Cut back on foods and beverages higher in these components to amounts that fit within healthy eating patterns.

4. Shift to healthier food and beverage choices. Choose nutrient-dense foods and beverages across and within all food groups in place of less healthy choices. Consider cultural and personal preferences to make these shifts easier to accomplish and maintain.

5. Support healthy eating patterns for all. Everyone has a role in helping to create and support healthy eating patterns in multiple settings nationwide, from home to school to work to communities. The chapter includes quantitative information on intakes and common sources of food groups, their subgroups, and other dietary components, including nutrients. The chapter also includes strategies to help shift current eating patterns toward the healthy patterns described in Chapter 1. Complementary strategies to support individuals in their effort to make shifts are discussed in greater detail in Chapter 3. Everyone Has a Role in Supporting Healthy Eating Patterns.

More than half of the population is meeting or exceeding total grain and total protein foods recommendations, but, as discussed later in the chapter, are not meeting the recommendations for the subgroups within each of these food groups.

Most Americans exceed the recommendations for added sugars, saturated fats, and sodium.

In addition, the eating patterns of many are too high in calories. Calorie intake over time, in comparison to calorie needs, is best evaluated by measuring body weight status. The high percentage of the population that is overweight or obese suggests that many in the United States overconsume calories. As documented in the Introduction, Table I-1, more than two-thirds of all adults and nearly one- third of all children and youth in the United States are either overweight or obese.

Current eating patterns can be moved toward healthier eating patterns by making shifts in food choices over time. Making these shifts can help support a healthy body weight, meet nutrient needs, and lessen the risk for chronic disease.', 'Make half your plate fruits & vegetables.

- 1½ cups mixed vegetables (bell peppers, snap peas, mushrooms)

2. Toss sweet potato cubes and vegetables with olive oil, salt, and pepper; spread on baking sheet. Roast 20-25 minutes.

4. Serve salmon with roasted veggies and sweet potato.

Table A4-1. (continued...) Healthy Mediterranean-Style Eating Pattern: Recommended Amounts of Food From Each Food Group at 12 Calorie Levels', 'About This Chapter

This chapter focuses on the fourth Dietary Guideline:

1. Follow a healthy eating pattern across the lifespan. All food and beverage choices matter. Choose a healthy eating pattern at an appropriate calorie level to help achieve and maintain a healthy body weight, support nutrient adequacy, and reduce the risk of chronic disease.

2. Focus on variety, nutrient density,

and amount. To meet nutrient needs within calorie limits, choose a variety of nutrient-dense foods across and within all food groups in recommended amounts.

3. Limit calories from added sugars and saturated fats and reduce sodium intake. Consume an

eating pattern low in added sugars, saturated fats, and sodium. Cut back on foods and beverages higher in these components to amounts that fit within healthy eating patterns.

4. Shift to healthier food and beverage choices. Choose nutrient-dense foods and beverages across and within all food groups in place of less healthy choices. Consider cultural and personal preferences to make these shifts easier to accomplish and maintain.

5. Support healthy eating patterns for all. Everyone has a role in helping to create and support healthy eating patterns in multiple settings nationwide, from home to school to work to communities. The chapter includes quantitative information on intakes and common sources of food groups, their subgroups, and other dietary components, including nutrients. The chapter also includes strategies to help shift current eating patterns toward the healthy patterns described in Chapter 1. Complementary strategies to support individuals in their effort to make shifts are discussed in greater detail in Chapter 3. Everyone Has a Role in Supporting Healthy Eating Patterns.

More than half of the population is meeting or exceeding total grain and total protein foods recommendations, but, as discussed later in the chapter, are not meeting the recommendations for the subgroups within each of these food groups.

Most Americans exceed the recommendations for added sugars, saturated fats, and sodium.

In addition, the eating patterns of many are too high in calories. Calorie intake over time, in comparison to calorie needs, is best evaluated by measuring body weight status. The high percentage of the population that is overweight or obese suggests that many in the United States overconsume calories. As documented in the Introduction, Table I-1, more than two-thirds of all adults and nearly one- third of all children and youth in the United States are either overweight or obese.

Current eating patterns can be moved toward healthier eating patterns by making shifts in food choices over time. Making these shifts can help support a healthy body weight, meet nutrient needs, and lessen the risk for chronic disease.', 'Protein Foods

Healthy Intake: Healthy eating patterns include a variety of protein foods in nutrient-dense forms. The protein foods group comprises a broad group of foods

Page 23 — 2015-2020 Dietary Guidelines for Americans • Chapter 1

from both animal and plant sources and includes several subgroups: seafood; meats, poultry, and eggs; and nuts, seeds, and soy products. Legumes (beans and peas) may also be considered part of the protein foods group as well as the vegetables group (see the About Legumes (Beans and Peas) call-out box). Protein also is found in some foods from other food groups (e.g., dairy). The recommendation for protein foods in the Healthy U.S.-Style Eating Pattern at the 2,000-calorie level is 5½ ounce- equivalents of protein foods per day.

Key Nutrient Contributions: Protein foods are important sources of nutrients in addition to protein, including B vitamins (e.g., niacin, vitamin B12, vitamin B6, and riboflavin), selenium, choline, phosphorus, zinc, copper, vitamin D, and vitamin E). Nutrients provided by various types of protein foods differ. For example, meats provide the most zinc, while poultry provides the most niacin. Meats, poultry, and seafood provide heme iron, which is more bioavailable than the non-heme iron found in plant sources. Heme iron is especially important for young children and women who are capable of becoming pregnant or who are pregnant. Seafood provides the most vitamin B12 and vitamin D, in addition to almost all of the polyunsaturated omega-3 fatty acids, eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA), and docosahexaenoic acid (DHA), in the Patterns (see the About Seafood call-out box). Eggs provide the most choline, and nuts and seeds provide the most vitamin E. Soy products are a source of copper, manganese, and iron, as are legumes.

Considerations: For balance and flexibility within the food group, the Healthy U.S.\xad Style Eating Pattern includes weekly recommendations for the subgroups: seafood; meats, poultry, and eggs; and nuts, seeds, and soy products. A specific

recommendation for at least 8 ounce- equivalents of seafood per week also is included for the 2,000-calorie level (see the About Seafood call-out box). One-half ounce of nuts or seeds counts as 1 ounce-equivalent of protein foods, and because they are high in calories, they should be eaten in small portions

and used to replace other protein foods rather than being added to the diet. When selecting protein foods, nuts and seeds should be unsalted, and meats and poultry should be consumed in lean forms. Processed meats and processed poultry are sources of sodium and saturated fats, and intake of these products can

be accommodated as long as sodium, saturated fats, added sugars, and total calories are within limits in the resulting eating pattern (see the About Meats and Poultry call-out box). The inclusion of protein foods from plants allows vegetarian options to be accommodated.', 'Food Groupa

The Healthy U.S.-Style Eating Pattern is designed to meet the Recommended Dietary Allowances (RDA) and Adequate Intakes for essential nutrients, as well as Acceptable Macronutrient Distribution Ranges (AMDR)

set by the Food and Nutrition Board of the IOM. This eating pattern also conforms to limits set by the IOM or Dietary Guidelines for other nutrients or food components (see Appendix 6. Glossary of Terms and Appendix 7.

Nutritional Goals for Age-Sex Groups Based on Dietary Reference Intakes and Dietary Guidelines Recommendations). Nutritional goals for almost all nutrients are met (see Appendix 3 for additional information).

Figure 1-1. Cup- & Ounce-Equivalents Within a food group, foods can come in many forms and are not created equal in terms of what counts as a cup or an ounce. Some foods are more concentrated, and some are more airy or contain more water. Cup- and ounce-equivalents identify the amounts of foods from each food group with similar nutritional content. In addition, portion sizes do not always align with one cup-equivalent or one ounce-equivalent. See examples below for variability.', '27 g/day

Pattern, taking into account food group intakes from studies examining the associations between Mediterranean- Style eating patterns and health.

The Healthy Mediterranean-Style Eating Pattern contains more fruits and seafood and less dairy than does the Healthy U.S.\xad Style Eating Pattern. The healthfulness of the Healthy Mediterranean-Style Pattern was evaluated based on its similarity to Mediterranean-Style patterns described in studies with positive health outcomes rather than on meeting specified nutrient standards. However, nutrient content of the Pattern was assessed and found to be similar to the Healthy U.S.-Style Eating Pattern, except for calcium and vitamin D. Calcium and vitamin D are lower because the amounts of dairy were decreased, as shown in Appendix 4, to more closely match data from studies of Mediterranean-Style eating patterns.']","# Meal Plan Overview

This meal plan is designed for an active male (180 cm, 80 kg) who prefers a high-protein diet with balanced macros including lean meats and plenty of vegetables. It supports general fitness maintenance and muscle support with about 2.2 g protein/kg body weight daily, moderate carbs for energy, and healthy fats. Meals use simple, accessible ingredients with variety throughout the week and no repetitive meals more than twice.

## Recipe 1: Turkey Meatballs with Tomato Sauce
- Italian herbs, salt, pepper to taste
2. In a bowl, mix turkey, egg, garlic, onion, salt, pepper, and herbs. Form into meatballs.
3. Heat olive oil in a pan and brown meatballs on all sides.
4. Add crushed tomatoes and simmer for 10 minutes until cooked through.
5. Serve over whole wheat spaghetti or with salad.
## Recipe 2: Chicken and Vegetable Stir Fry
- 1 cup mixed vegetables (broccoli, bell peppers, carrots)
1. Heat olive oil in a wok or pan over medium heat.
2. Add garlic and chicken slices, cook until no longer pink (about 5 min).
3. Add vegetables and stir fry for another 5-7 minutes until tender but crisp.
4. Add soy sauce and toss well. Serve with brown rice.
1. Blend oats into a flour consistency.
2. Mix oat flour, eggs, whey protein, and almond milk until smooth batter forms.
3. Heat a non-stick pan, pour batter forming pancakes, cook 2-3 min each side until golden.
## Recipe 4: Baked Salmon with Sweet Potato
- Lemon juice, herbs (dill or parsley), salt, and pepper
2. Slice sweet potato into chunks, toss with half tsp olive oil, salt, pepper — roast 20-25 minutes.
3. Place salmon on baking sheet, drizzle with lemon juice, herbs, and remaining oil. Bake for 15-18 minutes.
4. Serve salmon with roasted sweet potato and steamed green beans.
This plan balances high protein intake spread across meals, paired with ample vegetables and quality carbs to sustain an active lifestyle and support lean muscle maintenance."

jane.smith6@example.com,FitLife2025!,Jane,Smith,1985-07-15,F,165,60,Active,High-protein balanced diet,"I want a high-protein meal plan with around 2400 calories focusing on lean meats, vegetables, and healthy fats.","# Meal Plan Overview

This 7-day meal plan emphasizes lean meats (chicken, turkey, fish), plenty of vegetables, and healthy fats (avocado, nuts, olive oil). Carbohydrates come primarily from whole grains and vegetables to provide sustained energy. Protein is prioritized to support muscle maintenance and overall health. Meals are balanced, realistic, and use simple ingredients easy to prepare and substitute.

column1: - Turkey breast slices and ground turkey (~600g)
- Tilapia and cod (or other white fish) (~300g)

## Recipe 1: Grilled Chicken Breast with Quinoa and Steamed Veggies
- Salt, pepper, garlic powder, and herbs to taste
1. Season chicken breast with salt, pepper, garlic powder, and herbs. Grill until fully cooked (~6-7 minutes per side).
2. Cook quinoa as per package instructions.
3. Steam broccoli and carrots until tender.
4. Drizzle olive oil over vegetables before serving.
5. Serve chicken with quinoa and vegetables.
## Recipe 2: Turkey Meatballs with Cauliflower Rice and Roasted Vegetables
- 1 cup mixed zucchini and bell peppers
1. Mix ground turkey with seasoning, form into small meatballs. Pan-fry or bake at 375°F (190°C) until cooked through (~15-20 min).
2. Roast zucchini and bell peppers tossed in olive oil and seasoning in oven at 400°F (200°C) for 20 minutes.
3. Sauté cauliflower rice lightly in a non-stick pan for 5 minutes.
4. Serve meatballs over cauliflower rice with roasted veggies.
- 1 tbsp peanut butter or almond butter

The high percentage of the population that is overweight or obese suggests that many in the United States overconsume calories. As documented in the Introduction, Table I-1, more than two-thirds of all adults and nearly one- third of all children and youth in the United States are either overweight or obese.

Current eating patterns can be moved toward healthier eating patterns by making shifts in food choices over time. Making these shifts can help support a healthy body weight, meet nutrient needs, and lessen the risk for chronic disease.', 'Food Groupa

Designed for an active woman (165 cm, 60 kg) who prefers a high-protein balanced diet. This plan supports muscle maintenance and overall balanced nutrition with moderate carbs and healthy fats, good for energy and recovery. Meals include lean proteins, whole grains, vegetables, and healthy fats, with some variety to keep it interesting and nutrient-rich.

## Recipe 1: Turkey Meatballs with Whole Wheat Spaghetti
1. Mix ground turkey, garlic, parsley, and egg white. Form into small meatballs.
2. Heat olive oil in pan, cook meatballs until browned and cooked through (~10 minutes).
3. Warm tomato sauce and add meatballs to simmer for 5 minutes.
4. Cook spaghetti according to package. Serve meatballs and sauce over spaghetti.
- Spices: cumin, salt, pepper to taste
1. Heat olive oil in pot, sauté onion, carrot, celery, and garlic until softened (~5 min).
2. Add lentils, broth, and spices. Bring to boil.
3. Simmer 20-25 minutes until lentils are tender.
2. Mix oat flour, protein powder, egg whites, baking powder, and liquid until batter forms.
3. Cook on non-stick skillet over medium heat ~2-3 minutes each side until golden.
4. Serve with fresh berries and a light drizzle of syrup or honey.

This high-protein, low-carb meal plan is designed to provide sufficient protein for muscle support and maintenance, while keeping carbohydrates low to align with your goals. Calories are set around 950 kcal per day to support fat loss or lean mass maintenance with moderate activity, suitable for your 165 cm, 60 kg profile with moderate activity. The plan includes nutrient-dense whole foods with good fat sources and fiber for digestive health. Meals are varied, simple, and balanced for taste and ease.

Managing calorie intake is fundamental to achieving and maintaining calorie balance—the balance between the calories taken in from foods and the calories expended from metabolic processes and physical activity. The best way to determine whether an eating pattern is at an appropriate number of calories is to monitor body weight and adjust calorie intake and expenditure in physical activity based on changes in weight over time.

All foods and many beverages contain calories, and the total number of calories varies depending on the macronutrients in a food. On average, carbohydrates and protein contain 4 calories per gram, fats contain 9 calories per gram, and alcohol has 7 calories per gram. The total number of calories a person needs each day varies depending on a number of factors, including the person’s age, sex, height, weight, and level of physical activity (see Appendix 2). In addition, a need to lose, maintain, or gain weight and other factors affect how many calories should be consumed.

All Americans—children, adolescents, adults, and older adults—are encouraged to achieve and/or maintain a healthy body weight. General guidance for achieving and maintaining a healthy body weight is provided below, and Appendix 8. Federal Resources for Information on Nutrition and Physical Activity provides additional resources, including an evolving array of tools to facilitate Americans’ adoption of healthy choices.

Children and adolescents are encouraged to maintain calorie balance to support normal growth and

development without promoting excess weight gain. Children and adolescents who are overweight or obese should change their eating and physical activity behaviors to maintain or reduce their rate of weight gain while linear growth occurs, so that they can reduce body mass index (BMI) percentile toward a healthy range.

Before becoming pregnant, women are encouraged to achieve and maintain a healthy weight, and

women who are pregnant are encouraged to gain weight within gestational weight gain guidelines.[8]

Adults who are obese should change their eating and physical activity behaviors to prevent additional weight gain and/or promote weight loss. Adults who are overweight should not gain additional weight, and those with one or more CVD risk factors (e.g., hypertension and hyperlipidemia) should change their eating and physical activity behaviors to lose weight. To lose weight, most people need to reduce the number of calories they get from foods and beverages and increase their physical activity. For a weight loss of 1 to 1½ pounds per week, daily intake should be reduced by 500 to 750 calories. Eating patterns that contain 1,200 to 1,500 calories each day can help most women lose weight safely, and eating patterns that contain 1,500 to 1,800 calories each day are suitable for most men for weight loss. In adults who are overweight or obese, if reduction in total calorie intake is achieved, a variety of eating patterns can produce weight loss, particularly in the first 6 months to 2 years;[9] however, more research is needed on the health implications of consuming these eating patterns long-term.

Older adults, ages 65 years and older, who are overweight or obese are encouraged to prevent additional

weight gain. Among older adults who are obese, particularly those with CVD risk factors, intentional weight loss can be beneficial and result in improved quality of life and reduced risk of chronic diseases and associated disabilities.

[8] Institute of Medicine (IOM) and National Research Council (NRC). Weight gain during pregnancy: Reexamining the guidelines. Washington (DC): The National Academies Press; 2009.', 'About This Chapter

This chapter focuses on the fourth Dietary Guideline:

1. Follow a healthy eating pattern across the lifespan. All food and beverage choices matter. Choose a healthy eating pattern at an appropriate calorie level to help achieve and maintain a healthy body weight, support nutrient adequacy, and reduce the risk of chronic disease.

2. Focus on variety, nutrient density,

and amount. To meet nutrient needs within calorie limits, choose a variety of nutrient-dense foods across and within all food groups in recommended amounts.

3. Limit calories from added sugars and saturated fats and reduce sodium intake. Consume an

eating pattern low in added sugars, saturated fats, and sodium. Cut back on foods and beverages higher in these components to amounts that fit within healthy eating patterns.

4. Shift to healthier food and beverage choices. Choose nutrient-dense foods and beverages across and within all food groups in place of less healthy choices. Consider cultural and personal preferences to make these shifts easier to accomplish and maintain.

5. Support healthy eating patterns for all. Everyone has a role in helping to create and support healthy eating patterns in multiple settings nationwide, from home to school to work to communities. The chapter includes quantitative information on intakes and common sources of food groups, their subgroups, and other dietary components, including nutrients. The chapter also includes strategies to help shift current eating patterns toward the healthy patterns described in Chapter 1. Complementary strategies to support individuals in their effort to make shifts are discussed in greater detail in Chapter 3. Everyone Has a Role in Supporting Healthy Eating Patterns.

More than half of the population is meeting or exceeding total grain and total protein foods recommendations, but, as discussed later in the chapter, are not meeting the recommendations for the subgroups within each of these food groups.

Most Americans exceed the recommendations for added sugars, saturated fats, and sodium.

In addition, the eating patterns of many are too high in calories. Calorie intake over time, in comparison to calorie needs, is best evaluated by measuring body weight status. The high percentage of the population that is overweight or obese suggests that many in the United States overconsume calories. As documented in the Introduction, Table I-1, more than two-thirds of all adults and nearly one- third of all children and youth in the United States are either overweight or obese.

Current eating patterns can be moved toward healthier eating patterns by making shifts in food choices over time. Making these shifts can help support a healthy body weight, meet nutrient needs, and lessen the risk for chronic disease.', 'Source of Goal[a]

Figure 1-1. Cup- & Ounce-Equivalents Within a food group, foods can come in many forms and are not created equal in terms of what counts as a cup or an ounce. Some foods are more concentrated, and some are more airy or contain more water. Cup- and ounce-equivalents identify the amounts of foods from each food group with similar nutritional content. In addition, portion sizes do not always align with one cup-equivalent or one ounce-equivalent. See examples below for variability.']","# Meal Plan Overview

This meal plan is designed for a moderately active 33-year-old female, 165 cm, 60 kg, aiming for a balanced macronutrient distribution to support general health and maintain current weight. Meals incorporate a variety of nutrient-dense whole foods, easy-to-prepare recipes, and balanced portions of protein, carbs, and healthy fats. Snacks are included for sustained energy throughout the day.

Given your profile (Female, 165 cm, 60 kg, moderate activity) and your goal for a high-protein, balanced meal plan at around 1000 calories/day, I will design a realistic and nutrient-dense plan to support lean muscle maintenance and overall health.

Please note: 1000 kcal/day is very low for an adult with moderate activity; such calorie restriction should be temporary and carefully monitored. This plan emphasizes protein while balancing carbs and fats, meeting micronutrient needs as closely as possible within the low calorie limit.

- Notes: High-protein focus with lean meats, dairy, legumes; controlled calories; balanced macros; includes vegetables for fiber and micronutrients. Two optional low-calorie snacks included on some days to help avoid excess hunger.

Please let me know if you want adjustments such as vegetarian options, different calorie targets, or specific food preferences!","['Importance of Calorie Balance Within Healthy Eating Patterns

Managing calorie intake is fundamental to achieving and maintaining calorie balance—the balance between the calories taken in from foods and the calories expended from metabolic processes and physical activity. The best way to determine whether an eating pattern is at an appropriate number of calories is to monitor body weight and adjust calorie intake and expenditure in physical activity based on changes in weight over time.

All foods and many beverages contain calories, and the total number of calories varies depending on the macronutrients in a food. On average, carbohydrates and protein contain 4 calories per gram, fats contain 9 calories per gram, and alcohol has 7 calories per gram. The total number of calories a person needs each day varies depending on a number of factors, including the person’s age, sex, height, weight, and level of physical activity (see Appendix 2). In addition, a need to lose, maintain, or gain weight and other factors affect how many calories should be consumed.

All Americans—children, adolescents, adults, and older adults—are encouraged to achieve and/or maintain a healthy body weight. General guidance for achieving and maintaining a healthy body weight is provided below, and Appendix 8. Federal Resources for Information on Nutrition and Physical Activity provides additional resources, including an evolving array of tools to facilitate Americans’ adoption of healthy choices.

Children and adolescents are encouraged to maintain calorie balance to support normal growth and

development without promoting excess weight gain. Children and adolescents who are overweight or obese should change their eating and physical activity behaviors to maintain or reduce their rate of weight gain while linear growth occurs, so that they can reduce body mass index (BMI) percentile toward a healthy range.

Before becoming pregnant, women are encouraged to achieve and maintain a healthy weight, and

women who are pregnant are encouraged to gain weight within gestational weight gain guidelines.[8]

Adults who are obese should change their eating and physical activity behaviors to prevent additional weight gain and/or promote weight loss. Adults who are overweight should not gain additional weight, and those with one or more CVD risk factors (e.g., hypertension and hyperlipidemia) should change their eating and physical activity behaviors to lose weight. To lose weight, most people need to reduce the number of calories they get from foods and beverages and increase their physical activity. For a weight loss of 1 to 1½ pounds per week, daily intake should be reduced by 500 to 750 calories. Eating patterns that contain 1,200 to 1,500 calories each day can help most women lose weight safely, and eating patterns that contain 1,500 to 1,800 calories each day are suitable for most men for weight loss. In adults who are overweight or obese, if reduction in total calorie intake is achieved, a variety of eating patterns can produce weight loss, particularly in the first 6 months to 2 years;[9] however, more research is needed on the health implications of consuming these eating patterns long-term.

Older adults, ages 65 years and older, who are overweight or obese are encouraged to prevent additional

weight gain. Among older adults who are obese, particularly those with CVD risk factors, intentional weight loss can be beneficial and result in improved quality of life and reduced risk of chronic diseases and associated disabilities.

[8] Institute of Medicine (IOM) and National Research Council (NRC). Weight gain during pregnancy: Reexamining the guidelines. Washington (DC): The National Academies Press; 2009.', 'About This Chapter

This chapter focuses on the fourth Dietary Guideline:

1. Follow a healthy eating pattern across the lifespan. All food and beverage choices matter. Choose a healthy eating pattern at an appropriate calorie level to help achieve and maintain a healthy body weight, support nutrient adequacy, and reduce the risk of chronic disease.

2. Focus on variety, nutrient density,

and amount. To meet nutrient needs within calorie limits, choose a variety of nutrient-dense foods across and within all food groups in recommended amounts.

3. Limit calories from added sugars and saturated fats and reduce sodium intake. Consume an

eating pattern low in added sugars, saturated fats, and sodium. Cut back on foods and beverages higher in these components to amounts that fit within healthy eating patterns.

4. Shift to healthier food and beverage choices. Choose nutrient-dense foods and beverages across and within all food groups in place of less healthy choices. Consider cultural and personal preferences to make these shifts easier to accomplish and maintain.

5. Support healthy eating patterns for all. Everyone has a role in helping to create and support healthy eating patterns in multiple settings nationwide, from home to school to work to communities. The chapter includes quantitative information on intakes and common sources of food groups, their subgroups, and other dietary components, including nutrients. The chapter also includes strategies to help shift current eating patterns toward the healthy patterns described in Chapter 1. Complementary strategies to support individuals in their effort to make shifts are discussed in greater detail in Chapter 3. Everyone Has a Role in Supporting Healthy Eating Patterns.

More than half of the population is meeting or exceeding total grain and total protein foods recommendations, but, as discussed later in the chapter, are not meeting the recommendations for the subgroups within each of these food groups.

Most Americans exceed the recommendations for added sugars, saturated fats, and sodium.

In addition, the eating patterns of many are too high in calories. Calorie intake over time, in comparison to calorie needs, is best evaluated by measuring body weight status. The high percentage of the population that is overweight or obese suggests that many in the United States overconsume calories. As documented in the Introduction, Table I-1, more than two-thirds of all adults and nearly one- third of all children and youth in the United States are either overweight or obese.

Current eating patterns can be moved toward healthier eating patterns by making shifts in food choices over time. Making these shifts can help support a healthy body weight, meet nutrient needs, and lessen the risk for chronic disease.', 'Source of Goal[a]

1.6', 'A healthy eating pattern limits:

Saturated fats and trans fats, added sugars, and sodium

Key Recommendations that are quantitative are provided for several components of the diet that should be limited. These components are of particular public health concern in the United States, and the specified limits can help individuals achieve healthy eating patterns within calorie limits:

Consume less than 10 percent of calories per day from added sugars[2]

Consume less than 10 percent of calories per day from saturated fats[3]

Consume less than 2,300 milligrams (mg) per day of sodium[4]

If alcohol is consumed, it should be consumed in moderation—up to one drink per day for women and

up to two drinks per day for men—and only by adults of legal drinking age.[5]

In tandem with the recommendations above, Americans of all ages—children, adolescents, adults, and older adults—should meet the Physical Activity Guidelines for Americans to help promote health and reduce the risk of chronic disease. Americans should aim to achieve and maintain a healthy body weight. The relationship between diet and physical activity contributes to calorie balance and managing body weight. As such, the Dietary Guidelines includes a Key Recommendation to:

Meet the Physical Activity Guidelines for Americans.[6]

[1] Definitions for each food group and subgroup are provided throughout Chapter 1: Key Elements of Healthy Eating Patterns and are compiled in Appendix 3. USDA Food Patterns: Healthy U.S.-Style Eating Pattern.

[2] The recommendation to limit intake of calories from added sugars to less than 10 percent per day is a target based on food pattern modeling and national data on intakes of calories from added sugars that demonstrate the public health need to limit calories from added sugars to meet food group and nutrient needs within calorie limits. The limit on calories from added sugars is not a Tolerable Upper Intake Level (UL) set by the Institute of Medicine (IOM). For most calorie levels, there are not enough calories available after meeting food group needs to consume 10 percent of calories from added sugars and 10 percent of calories from saturated fats and still stay within calorie limits.

[3] The recommendation to limit intake of calories from saturated fats to less than 10 percent per day is a target based on evidence that replacing saturated fats with unsaturated fats is associated with reduced risk of cardiovascular disease. The limit on calories from saturated fats is not a UL set by the IOM. For most calorie levels, there are not enough calories available after meeting food group needs to consume 10 percent of calories from added sugars and 10 percent of calories from saturated fats and still stay within calorie limits.

[4] The recommendation to limit intake of sodium to less than 2,300 mg per day is the UL for individuals ages 14 years and older set by the IOM. The recommendations for children younger than 14 years of age are the IOM age- and sex-appropriate ULs (see Appendix 7. Nutritional Goals for Age-Sex Groups Based on Dietary Reference Intakes and Dietary Guidelines Recommendations).

[5] It is not recommended that individuals begin drinking or drink more for any reason. The amount of alcohol and calories in beverages varies and should be accounted for within the limits of healthy eating patterns. Alcohol should be consumed only by adults of legal drinking age. There are many circumstances in which individuals should not drink, such as during pregnancy. See Appendix 9. Alcohol for additional information.

[6] U.S. Department of Health and Human Services. 2008 Physical Activity Guidelines for Americans. Washington (DC): U.S. Department of Health and Human Services; 2008. ODPHP Publication No. U0036. Available at: https://odphp.health.gov/paguidelines. Accessed August 6, 2015.

[a] Food intake patterns at 1,000, 1,200, and 1,400 calories are designed to meet the nutritional needs of 2- to 8-year-old children. Patterns from 1,600 to 3,200 calories are designed to meet the nutritional needs of children 9 years and older and adults. If a child 4 to 8 years of age needs more calories and, therefore, is following a pattern at 1,600 calories or more, his/her recommended amount from the dairy group should be 2.5 cups per day. Children 9 years and older and adults should not use the 1,000-, 1,200-, or 1,400-calorie patterns.

[b] Foods in each group and subgroup are:

Vegetables

Dark-green vegetables: All fresh, frozen, and canned dark-green leafy vegetables and broccoli, cooked or raw: for example, broccoli; spinach; romaine; kale; collard, turnip, and mustard greens.

Red and orange vegetables: All fresh, frozen, and canned red and orange vegetables or juice, cooked or raw: for example, tomatoes, tomato juice, red peppers, carrots, sweet potatoes, winter squash, and pumpkin.

Legumes (beans and peas): All cooked from dry or canned beans and peas: for example, kidney beans, white beans, black beans, lentils, chickpeas, pinto beans, split peas, and edamame (green soybeans). Does not include green beans or green peas.

Snacks are optional and nutrient-dense for flexibility.

column1: ## Recipe 1: Quinoa Salad with Chickpeas and Lemon Dressing
1. In a large bowl, combine cooked quinoa and chickpeas.
2. Add diced tomato, cucumber, and chopped parsley.
3. In a small bowl, whisk lemon juice, olive oil, salt, and pepper.
4. Pour dressing over salad and toss gently. Serve chilled.
## Recipe 2: Turkey Meatballs with Whole Wheat Spaghetti
2. In a bowl, mix turkey, breadcrumbs, egg, garlic, seasoning, salt, and pepper. Form small meatballs.
3. Place meatballs on a baking sheet and bake for 20 minutes or until cooked through.
4. Cook spaghetti according to package instructions.
5. Heat tomato sauce in a pan, add meatballs and coat them well. Serve meatballs and sauce over spaghetti.
## Recipe 3: Baked Salmon with Sweet Potato and Asparagus
2. Toss sweet potato cubes with half the olive oil, salt, and pepper; spread on baking sheet. Roast 20 minutes.
3. Add asparagus and salmon to baking sheet; drizzle remaining olive oil on salmon and season with salt and pepper.
4. Roast for another 12-15 minutes until salmon is cooked and vegetables are tender.
This plan offers balanced meals with variety, suitable for Jane's moderate activity level and balanced macro preference while maintaining overall health and stable energy."

- Protein (average per day): 130 g (approx. 29% of calories)
- Carbs (average per day): 180 g (approx. 40% of calories)
- Fat (average per day): 60 g (approx. 30% of calories)

This plan focuses on high-protein intake distributed throughout the day to support muscle maintenance and recovery, with moderate carbohydrates to fuel activity and healthy fats for overall wellness. Meals are balanced, using whole and nutrient-dense foods, suitable for moderate activity levels. The variety ensures sufficient micronutrients and fiber.

## Recipe 1: Grilled Chicken Breast with Quinoa and Steamed Broccoli
1. Season chicken breast with salt, pepper, and your choice of herbs.
2. Grill or pan-cook the chicken until internal temperature reaches 75°C (165°F).
3. Cook quinoa according to package instructions.
5. Drizzle olive oil over quinoa and broccoli or use it to sauté the chicken.
- 1/4 cup oats (blended into flour or whole)
1. Blend oats into flour if desired.
2. Mix protein powder, oat flour, egg whites, and almond milk into a batter.
3. Heat non-stick pan and pour small portions to form pancakes.
4. Cook 2-3 minutes each side until golden.
## Recipe 3: Baked Salmon with Sweet Potato and Salad
- Olive oil for dressing and cooking
2. Season salmon with salt, pepper, and lemon juice.
3. Peel and slice sweet potato; bake or roast for 25-30 minutes until tender.
4. Bake salmon for 15-20 minutes until cooked through.
5. Toss mixed greens with sliced avocado and olive oil dressing.
6. Serve salmon with sweet potato and salad.
## Recipe 4: Turkey Meatballs with Brown Rice and Broccoli
1. Mix ground turkey with seasonings and shape into small meatballs.
2. Bake at 200°C (400°F) for 15-20 minutes or until fully cooked.
3. Cook brown rice as per instructions.
5. Serve meatballs with rice and broccoli.

1.6', 'Protein Foods

Healthy Intake: Healthy eating patterns include a variety of protein foods in nutrient-dense forms. The protein foods group comprises a broad group of foods

Page 23 — 2015-2020 Dietary Guidelines for Americans • Chapter 1

from both animal and plant sources and includes several subgroups: seafood; meats, poultry, and eggs; and nuts, seeds, and soy products. Legumes (beans and peas) may also be considered part of the protein foods group as well as the vegetables group (see the About Legumes (Beans and Peas) call-out box). Protein also is found in some foods from other food groups (e.g., dairy). The recommendation for protein foods in the Healthy U.S.-Style Eating Pattern at the 2,000-calorie level is 5½ ounce- equivalents of protein foods per day.

Key Nutrient Contributions: Protein foods are important sources of nutrients in addition to protein, including B vitamins (e.g., niacin, vitamin B12, vitamin B6, and riboflavin), selenium, choline, phosphorus, zinc, copper, vitamin D, and vitamin E). Nutrients provided by various types of protein foods differ. For example, meats provide the most zinc, while poultry provides the most niacin. Meats, poultry, and seafood provide heme iron, which is more bioavailable than the non-heme iron found in plant sources. Heme iron is especially important for young children and women who are capable of becoming pregnant or who are pregnant. Seafood provides the most vitamin B12 and vitamin D, in addition to almost all of the polyunsaturated omega-3 fatty acids, eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA), and docosahexaenoic acid (DHA), in the Patterns (see the About Seafood call-out box). Eggs provide the most choline, and nuts and seeds provide the most vitamin E. Soy products are a source of copper, manganese, and iron, as are legumes.

Considerations: For balance and flexibility within the food group, the Healthy U.S.\xad Style Eating Pattern includes weekly recommendations for the subgroups: seafood; meats, poultry, and eggs; and nuts, seeds, and soy products. A specific

recommendation for at least 8 ounce- equivalents of seafood per week also is included for the 2,000-calorie level (see the About Seafood call-out box). One-half ounce of nuts or seeds counts as 1 ounce-equivalent of protein foods, and because they are high in calories, they should be eaten in small portions

and used to replace other protein foods rather than being added to the diet. When selecting protein foods, nuts and seeds should be unsalted, and meats and poultry should be consumed in lean forms. Processed meats and processed poultry are sources of sodium and saturated fats, and intake of these products can

be accommodated as long as sodium, saturated fats, added sugars, and total calories are within limits in the resulting eating pattern (see the About Meats and Poultry call-out box). The inclusion of protein foods from plants allows vegetarian options to be accommodated.', 'Summary

The 2015-2020 Dietary Guidelines provides Guidelines and Key Recommendations with clear guidance for individuals to enhance eating and physical activity patterns. Implementation of these Guidelines will help promote health and prevent chronic disease in the United States. At the core of this guidance is the importance of consuming overall healthy eating patterns, including vegetables, fruits, grains, dairy, protein foods, and oils—eaten within an appropriate calorie level and in forms with limited amounts of saturated fats, added sugars, and sodium. Examples of how to put this guidance into practice are provided by the Healthy U.S.-Style Eating Pattern and its two variations, a Healthy Mediterranean-Style Eating Pattern and a Healthy Vegetarian Eating Pattern.

2015-2020 Dietary Guidelines for Americans • Chapter 1 — Page 36

CHAPTER

2

Shifts Needed To Align With Healthy Eating Patterns

Page 37 — 2015-2020 Dietary Guidelines for Americans • Chapter 2

Introduction

F ollowing healthy eating patterns is

vital to health. This chapter provides a snapshot of current eating patterns of

people in the United States in comparison to the recommendations in Chapter 1. Key Elements of Healthy Eating Patterns and describes shifts that are needed to align current intakes to recommendations. In some cases, the news is good—for certain aspects of eating patterns, some individuals are following the guidance or are close to meeting the recommendations. However, other aspects of the diet are far from the recommendations. Most Americans would benefit from shifting food choices both within and across food groups and from current food choices to nutrient-dense choices. Some shifts that are needed are minor and can be accomplished by making simple substitutions, while others will require greater effort to accomplish.', 'About This Chapter

This chapter focuses on the fourth Dietary Guideline:

1. Follow a healthy eating pattern across the lifespan. All food and beverage choices matter. Choose a healthy eating pattern at an appropriate calorie level to help achieve and maintain a healthy body weight, support nutrient adequacy, and reduce the risk of chronic disease.

2. Focus on variety, nutrient density,

and amount. To meet nutrient needs within calorie limits, choose a variety of nutrient-dense foods across and within all food groups in recommended amounts.

3. Limit calories from added sugars and saturated fats and reduce sodium intake. Consume an

eating pattern low in added sugars, saturated fats, and sodium. Cut back on foods and beverages higher in these components to amounts that fit within healthy eating patterns.

4. Shift to healthier food and beverage choices. Choose nutrient-dense foods and beverages across and within all food groups in place of less healthy choices. Consider cultural and personal preferences to make these shifts easier to accomplish and maintain.

5. Support healthy eating patterns for all. Everyone has a role in helping to create and support healthy eating patterns in multiple settings nationwide, from home to school to work to communities. The chapter includes quantitative information on intakes and common sources of food groups, their subgroups, and other dietary components, including nutrients. The chapter also includes strategies to help shift current eating patterns toward the healthy patterns described in Chapter 1. Complementary strategies to support individuals in their effort to make shifts are discussed in greater detail in Chapter 3. Everyone Has a Role in Supporting Healthy Eating Patterns.

More than half of the population is meeting or exceeding total grain and total protein foods recommendations, but, as discussed later in the chapter, are not meeting the recommendations for the subgroups within each of these food groups.

Most Americans exceed the recommendations for added sugars, saturated fats, and sodium.

In addition, the eating patterns of many are too high in calories. Calorie intake over time, in comparison to calorie needs, is best evaluated by measuring body weight status. The high percentage of the population that is overweight or obese suggests that many in the United States overconsume calories. As documented in the Introduction, Table I-1, more than two-thirds of all adults and nearly one- third of all children and youth in the United States are either overweight or obese.

Current eating patterns can be moved toward healthier eating patterns by making shifts in food choices over time. Making these shifts can help support a healthy body weight, meet nutrient needs, and lessen the risk for chronic disease.', 'Food Groupa

In addition, portion sizes do not always align with one cup-equivalent or one ounce-equivalent. See examples below for variability.']","# Meal Plan Overview

This 7-day high-protein meal plan is balanced with moderate carbs and healthy fats tailored for Jane, a moderately active 60 kg female. The plan supports muscle maintenance and satiety with around 1800 kcal/day and ~30% calories from protein. Meals feature lean proteins, whole grains, vegetables, and healthy fats for sustainable energy and recovery. Snacks are included for energy balance and variety. Simple, accessible ingredients with some flexibility for substitutions.

james.martin7@example.com,FitLife2025!,James,Martin,1990-05-15,M,180,80,Active,"High protein, balanced fats, moderate carbs","I want a high-protein meal plan with around 2000 calories, focusing on lean meats, vegetables, and healthy fats.","# Meal Plan Overview
- Fat (average per day): ~60-70 g (primarily healthy fats)
- Focus on lean meats (chicken breast, turkey, fish), a variety of vegetables, and sources of healthy fats such as olive oil, avocado, nuts, and seeds.
- Moderate complex carbohydrates from whole grains and legumes to balance energy.
- Meals are balanced for nutrient-dense whole foods with minimal processed ingredients.
- Each day includes 3 main meals + 1–2 optional snacks.
- Variety ensured with different protein sources and vegetables across the week.

Current Intakes: Overall, average intakes of protein foods are close to amounts recommended for all age-sex groups (Figure 2-3). However, Figure 2-6 shows that the average intakes of protein foods subgroups vary in comparison to the range of intake recommendations. Overall, average intakes of seafood are low for all age-sex groups; average intakes of nuts, seeds, and soy products are close to recommended levels; and

average intakes of meats, poultry, and eggs are high for teen boys and adult men. Legumes (beans and peas), a vegetables subgroup, also may be considered as part of the protein foods group (see the About Legumes (Beans and Peas) call-out box in Chapter 1). As shown in Figure 2-4, intakes of legumes are below vegetable group recommendations.

Commonly consumed protein foods include beef (especially ground beef), chicken, pork, processed meats (e.g., hot dogs,

sausages, ham, luncheon meats), and eggs. The most common seafood choices are shrimp, tuna, and salmon; and the most common nut choices are peanuts, peanut butter, almonds, and mixed nuts. Slightly less than half (49%) of all protein foods are consumed as a separate food item, such as a chicken breast, a steak, an egg, a fish filet, or peanuts. About the same proportion are consumed as part of a mixed dish (45%), with the largest amount from burgers, sandwiches, and tacos.

Healthy Intake: Healthy eating patterns include a variety of protein foods in nutrient-dense forms. The protein foods group comprises a broad group of foods

Page 23 — 2015-2020 Dietary Guidelines for Americans • Chapter 1

from both animal and plant sources and includes several subgroups: seafood; meats, poultry, and eggs; and nuts, seeds, and soy products. Legumes (beans and peas) may also be considered part of the protein foods group as well as the vegetables group (see the About Legumes (Beans and Peas) call-out box). Protein also is found in some foods from other food groups (e.g., dairy). The recommendation for protein foods in the Healthy U.S.-Style Eating Pattern at the 2,000-calorie level is 5½ ounce- equivalents of protein foods per day.

Key Nutrient Contributions: Protein foods are important sources of nutrients in addition to protein, including B vitamins (e.g., niacin, vitamin B12, vitamin B6, and riboflavin), selenium, choline, phosphorus, zinc, copper, vitamin D, and vitamin E). Nutrients provided by various types of protein foods differ. For example, meats provide the most zinc, while poultry provides the most niacin. Meats, poultry, and seafood provide heme iron, which is more bioavailable than the non-heme iron found in plant sources. Heme iron is especially important for young children and women who are capable of becoming pregnant or who are pregnant. Seafood provides the most vitamin B12 and vitamin D, in addition to almost all of the polyunsaturated omega-3 fatty acids, eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA), and docosahexaenoic acid (DHA), in the Patterns (see the About Seafood call-out box). Eggs provide the most choline, and nuts and seeds provide the most vitamin E. Soy products are a source of copper, manganese, and iron, as are legumes.

Considerations: For balance and flexibility within the food group, the Healthy U.S.\xad Style Eating Pattern includes weekly recommendations for the subgroups: seafood; meats, poultry, and eggs; and nuts, seeds, and soy products. A specific

recommendation for at least 8 ounce- equivalents of seafood per week also is included for the 2,000-calorie level (see the About Seafood call-out box). One-half ounce of nuts or seeds counts as 1 ounce-equivalent of protein foods, and because they are high in calories, they should be eaten in small portions

and used to replace other protein foods rather than being added to the diet. When selecting protein foods, nuts and seeds should be unsalted, and meats and poultry should be consumed in lean forms. Processed meats and processed poultry are sources of sodium and saturated fats, and intake of these products can

be accommodated as long as sodium, saturated fats, added sugars, and total calories are within limits in the resulting eating pattern (see the About Meats and Poultry call-out box). The inclusion of protein foods from plants allows vegetarian options to be accommodated.', 'About This Chapter

This chapter focuses on the fourth Dietary Guideline:

1. Follow a healthy eating pattern across the lifespan. All food and beverage choices matter. Choose a healthy eating pattern at an appropriate calorie level to help achieve and maintain a healthy body weight, support nutrient adequacy, and reduce the risk of chronic disease.

2. Focus on variety, nutrient density,

and amount. To meet nutrient needs within calorie limits, choose a variety of nutrient-dense foods across and within all food groups in recommended amounts.

3. Limit calories from added sugars and saturated fats and reduce sodium intake. Consume an

eating pattern low in added sugars, saturated fats, and sodium. Cut back on foods and beverages higher in these components to amounts that fit within healthy eating patterns.

4. Shift to healthier food and beverage choices. Choose nutrient-dense foods and beverages across and within all food groups in place of less healthy choices. Consider cultural and personal preferences to make these shifts easier to accomplish and maintain.

5. Support healthy eating patterns for all. Everyone has a role in helping to create and support healthy eating patterns in multiple settings nationwide, from home to school to work to communities. The chapter includes quantitative information on intakes and common sources of food groups, their subgroups, and other dietary components, including nutrients. The chapter also includes strategies to help shift current eating patterns toward the healthy patterns described in Chapter 1. Complementary strategies to support individuals in their effort to make shifts are discussed in greater detail in Chapter 3. Everyone Has a Role in Supporting Healthy Eating Patterns.

More than half of the population is meeting or exceeding total grain and total protein foods recommendations, but, as discussed later in the chapter, are not meeting the recommendations for the subgroups within each of these food groups.

Most Americans exceed the recommendations for added sugars, saturated fats, and sodium.

In addition, the eating patterns of many are too high in calories. Calorie intake over time, in comparison to calorie needs, is best evaluated by measuring body weight status. The high percentage of the population that is overweight or obese suggests that many in the United States overconsume calories. As documented in the Introduction, Table I-1, more than two-thirds of all adults and nearly one- third of all children and youth in the United States are either overweight or obese.

Current eating patterns can be moved toward healthier eating patterns by making shifts in food choices over time. Making these shifts can help support a healthy body weight, meet nutrient needs, and lessen the risk for chronic disease.', 'Source of Goal[a]

Current Intakes: Overall, average intakes of protein foods are close to amounts recommended for all age-sex groups (Figure 2-3). However, Figure 2-6 shows that the average intakes of protein foods subgroups vary in comparison to the range of intake recommendations. Overall, average intakes of seafood are low for all age-sex groups; average intakes of nuts, seeds, and soy products are close to recommended levels; and

average intakes of meats, poultry, and eggs are high for teen boys and adult men. Legumes (beans and peas), a vegetables subgroup, also may be considered as part of the protein foods group (see the About Legumes (Beans and Peas) call-out box in Chapter 1). As shown in Figure 2-4, intakes of legumes are below vegetable group recommendations.

Commonly consumed protein foods include beef (especially ground beef), chicken, pork, processed meats (e.g., hot dogs,

sausages, ham, luncheon meats), and eggs. The most common seafood choices are shrimp, tuna, and salmon; and the most common nut choices are peanuts, peanut butter, almonds, and mixed nuts. Slightly less than half (49%) of all protein foods are consumed as a separate food item, such as a chicken breast, a steak, an egg, a fish filet, or peanuts. About the same proportion are consumed as part of a mixed dish (45%), with the largest amount from burgers, sandwiches, and tacos.

This plan is designed for an active 33-year-old male (180 cm, 80 kg) aiming to maintain weight with balanced macronutrient distribution. Meals focus on whole foods with a mix of lean proteins, complex carbs, healthy fats, and ample fiber for satiety and digestive health. Snacks provide convenient energy and nutrient boosts without excessive calories. Adjust portion sizes slightly if weight goals change.

column1: - Spices (curry powder, garlic, chili powder, salt, pepper)
## Recipe 1: Turkey Meatballs with Whole Wheat Pasta
1. Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C). Mix ground turkey with minced garlic, onion, salt, and pepper. Form into small meatballs.
2. Heat olive oil in pan, brown meatballs for 3-4 min on each side.
3. Transfer to baking dish, cover with marinara sauce, bake for 15 min until cooked.
4. Cook pasta according to package directions. Serve meatballs over pasta, sprinkle with parmesan cheese.
- Mixed vegetables (bell peppers, carrots, peas, 1 cup)
1. Heat olive oil in pan, sauté onion and garlic until translucent.
2. Add chicken pieces, cook until no longer pink.
3. Add curry powder, stir for 1 min, then add vegetables and coconut milk.
4. Simmer for 15-20 min until chicken is cooked through and sauce thickens. Serve with brown rice.
- Bell peppers and onions (1 cup total, sliced)
- Lime juice, cumin, chili powder (to taste)
1. Heat olive oil in skillet, sauté beef strips with cumin, chili powder until browned.
2. Add bell peppers and onions, cook until tender crisp.
3. Warm tortillas. Serve beef and veggies in tortillas with lime juice squeezed on top.
1. Blend all ingredients until smooth. Pour into bowl or glass. Enjoy immediately.

Current Intakes: Overall, average intakes of protein foods are close to amounts recommended for all age-sex groups (Figure 2-3). However, Figure 2-6 shows that the average intakes of protein foods subgroups vary in comparison to the range of intake recommendations. Overall, average intakes of seafood are low for all age-sex groups; average intakes of nuts, seeds, and soy products are close to recommended levels; and

average intakes of meats, poultry, and eggs are high for teen boys and adult men. Legumes (beans and peas), a vegetables subgroup, also may be considered as part of the protein foods group (see the About Legumes (Beans and Peas) call-out box in Chapter 1). As shown in Figure 2-4, intakes of legumes are below vegetable group recommendations.

Commonly consumed protein foods include beef (especially ground beef), chicken, pork, processed meats (e.g., hot dogs,

sausages, ham, luncheon meats), and eggs. The most common seafood choices are shrimp, tuna, and salmon; and the most common nut choices are peanuts, peanut butter, almonds, and mixed nuts. Slightly less than half (49%) of all protein foods are consumed as a separate food item, such as a chicken breast, a steak, an egg, a fish filet, or peanuts. About the same proportion are consumed as part of a mixed dish (45%), with the largest amount from burgers, sandwiches, and tacos.

Figure 2-6. Average Protein Foods Subgroup Intakes in Ounce-Equivalents per Week by Age-Sex Groups, Compared to Ranges of Recommended Intake', 'About Legumes (Beans & Peas)

Legumes include kidney beans, pinto beans, white beans, black beans, garbanzo beans (chickpeas), lima beans (mature, dried), split peas, lentils, and edamame (green soybeans).

Legumes are excellent sources of protein. In addition, they provide other nutrients that also are found in seafood, meats, and poultry, such as iron and zinc. They are excellent sources of dietary fiber and of nutrients, such as potassium and folate that also are found in other vegetables.

Because legumes have a similar nutrient profile to foods in both the protein foods group and the vegetable group, they may be thought of as either a vegetable or a protein food and thus, can be counted as a vegetable or a protein food to meet recommended intakes.

Green peas and green (string) beans are not counted in the legume subgroup, because their nutrient compositions are not similar to legumes. Green peas are similar to starchy vegetables and are grouped with them. Green beans are grouped with the other vegetables subgroup, which includes onions, iceberg lettuce, celery, and cabbage, because their nutrient content is not similar to legumes.

and orange vegetables the most vitamin A, legumes the most dietary fiber, and starchy vegetables the most potassium. Vegetables in the “other” vegetable subgroup provide a wide range of nutrients in varying amounts.

Considerations: To provide all of the nutrients and potential health benefits that vary across different types of vegetables, the Healthy U.S.-Style Eating Pattern includes weekly recommendations for each subgroup. Vegetable choices over time should vary and include many different vegetables. Vegetables should be consumed in a nutrient-dense form, with limited additions such as salt, butter, or creamy sauces. When selecting frozen or canned vegetables, choose those lower in sodium.

and 100% fruit juice. Whole fruits include fresh, canned, frozen, and dried forms. The recommended amount of fruits in the Healthy U.S.-Style Eating Pattern at the 2,000-calorie level is 2 cup-equivalents per day. One cup of 100% fruit juice counts as 1 cup of fruit. Although fruit juice can be part of healthy eating patterns, it is lower than whole fruit in dietary fiber and when consumed in excess can contribute extra calories. Therefore, at least half of the recommended amount of fruits should come from whole fruits. When juices are consumed, they should be 100% juice, without added sugars. Also, when selecting canned fruit, choose options that are lowest in added sugars. One-half cup of dried fruit counts as one cup-equivalent of fruit. Similar to juice, when consumed in excess, dried fruits can contribute extra calories.']","# Meal Plan Overview

This low-carb meal plan supports moderate activity and general health maintenance with a balanced intake of protein and fats to sustain energy. Carbs are kept moderate and primarily from fiber-rich vegetables and some fruits for vitamin and mineral support. Meals include simple, wholesome ingredients and offer variety while maintaining a low-carb focus.

Consume a healthy eating pattern that accounts for all foods and beverages within an appropriate calorie level.

A healthy eating pattern includes:[1]

A variety of vegetables from all of the subgroups—dark green, red and orange, legumes (beans and peas), starchy,

and other

Fruits, especially whole fruits

Grains, at least half of which are whole grains
